revision.comment: wikified: [[Harlem#West_Harlem|West Harlem]]
revision.text:
{{Infobox officeholder |name=Herman D. Farrell Jr. |image= |alt= |caption= |state_assembly=New York |district=71st |term_start=January 1, 1975 |term_end=September 5, 2017 |predecessor=[[Mark T. Southall]] |successor=[[Al Taylor (politician)|Al Taylor]] |birth_date={{birth date|1932|2|4}} |birth_place=[[New York City]], [[New York (state)|New York]], U.S. |death_date={{death date and age|2018|5|26|1932|2|4}} |death_place= [[New York City]], [[New York (state)|New York]], U.S. |birthname= |party=[[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] |spouse= |relations= |children=3 |alma_mater= |religion= |website= }} '''Herman Daniel “Denny” Farrell Jr.''' (February 4, 1932 – May 26, 2018) was an American politician from [[New York (state)|New York]]. He was a [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] member of the [[New York State Assembly]] representing the [[Manhattan]] neighborhoods of [[Harlem#West_Harlem|West Harlem]], [[Inwood, Manhattan|Inwood]] and [[Washington Heights, Manhattan|Washington Heights]] from 1975 to 2017. ==Early Life== Farrell was born February 4, 1932 in Manhattan. His parents, Herman, Sr. and Amy Gladys, owned a dress shop. He graduated from [[George Washington Educational Campus|George Washington High School]] in [[Washington Heights, Manhattan|Washington Heights]]. Before working in politics, he was a cook and an auto mechanic. He worked for Mayor [[John Lindsay]], then, in 1966, began work as a confidential aide to a state Supreme Court justice. ==Political career== In 1970, he was elected a Democratic state committeeman. First elected to the New York Assembly in 1974, Farrell was a longtime Chairman of the powerful Assembly Ways and Means Committee, as well as a member of the Assembly Rules Committee and the Black, Puerto Rican, Hispanic and Asian Legislative Caucus. He previously served as Chairman of the Assembly Committee on Banks from 1979 to 1994. Farrell played a pivotal role in the passage of several significant pieces of legislation, including the Omnibus Consumer Protection and Banking Legislation Act, which established a toll-free number at the New York State Banking Department that dispenses information about [[credit card interest]] rates, fees and grace periods, and a mandate for banks to furnish low-cost checking accounts to its customers. He also played an important role in the passage of the Neighborhood Preservation Companies Act, whereby New York State funds community organizations that "provide tenant advocacy." However, Farrell is most widely known for having been a prominent member of the state (and to a lesser extent, national) [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic Party]]. He was first elected as a Democratic State Committeeman in 1970, serving a two-year term. Subsequently, he was elected as the Leader of the [[Manhattan|New York County]] Democratic Party (1981-2009)[http://manhattandemocrats.org/about/county-leaders New York County Democratic Leaders] and Vice-Chair of the New York State Democratic Party, in which capacity he served for a decade. He was Chairman of the New York State Democratic Committee from 2001 to 2006. He also served as a member of the [[Democratic National Committee]]. Farrell resigned from the State Assembly in September 2017. ===Campaign for Mayor=== Farrell entered the Democratic primary against [[Ed Koch]] in the [[New York City mayoral election, 1985|1985 election for Mayor]]. Although Farrell’s entry into the race initially created some bad blood, [[David Dinkins]] credited him for paving the way for Dinkins’ victory in [[New York City mayoral election, 1989|1989]]. Farrell’s late entry into the race was a surprise to the party and caused a split between party leaders in Manhattan and the outer boroughs and between black and Latino politicians. At the time, Bronx Borough President [[Herman Badillo]] believed he would win the endorsement of the Coalition for a Just New York, one of the city’s black political organizations, to form a coalition that could unseat Koch.{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1985/02/18/nyregion/endorsement-of-farrell-splits-minority-caucus.html |title=Endorsement of Farrell Splits Minority Caucus |publisher=New York Times |date=1985-02-18}} He recovered from an attempt by Council President [[Carol Bellamy]] to remove him from the ballot but still fared poorly taking 13% of the vote and finishing third behind Bellamy and Koch.{{cite news |url=https://mobile.nytimes.com/1985/09/11/nyregion/koch-takes-primary-easily-stein-and-dinkins-also-win-backing-of-city-democrats.html |title=Koch Takes Primary Easily; Stein and Dinkins Also Win Backing of City Democrats |publisher=New York Times |date=1985-09-11}} Following the split, black leaders from around New York City met to settle past differences and focus on uniting for future elections. David Dinkins strength with black voters helped him defeat Koch in 1989 to become mayor.{{cite news |url=https://mobile.nytimes.com/1989/09/17/nyregion/blacks-started-dinkin-s-bid-in-a-symbolic-river-crossing.html |title=Blacks Started Dinkin's Bid In a Symbolic River-Crossing |publisher=New York Times |date=1989-09-17}} ==Later Life== A pedestrian bridge constructed in [[Riverside Park (Manhattan)|Riverside Park]] in late 2017 was named after Farrell as it is located within his Assembly district.Walsh, Kevin, [http://forgotten-ny.com/2018/01/herman-denny-farrell-bridge-washington-heights/ "Herman "Denny" Farrell Bridge"] January 16, 2018 Farrell died of heart failure on May 26, 2018, at the age of 86.{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/05/26/obituaries/herman-denny-farrell-jr.html |title=Herman D. Farrell Jr., of Harlem’s Political Old Guard, Dies at 86 |publisher=Nytimes.com |date= |accessdate=2018-05-27}}{{cite web|author=McShane, Larry |url=http://www.nydailynews.com/new-york/longtime-harlem-assemblyman-herman-farrell-dead-86-article-1.4011190 |title=Longtime Harlem assemblyman Herman Farrell dead at 86 |publisher=NY Daily News |date= |accessdate=2018-05-27}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20060913192600/http://www.nydems.org/html/electedofficials/farrell.html Biography: New York State Democratic Party] {{s-start}} {{s-par|us-ny-hs}} {{succession box | title = [[New York State Assembly]]
74th District | before = [[Mark T. Southall]] | years = 1975–1982 | after = [[Louis Niñé]]}} {{s-bef|before=[[Geraldine L. Daniels]]}} {{s-ttl|title=[[New York State Assembly]]
71st District|years=1983–2017}} {{s-aft|after=[[Al Taylor (politician)|Al Taylor]]}} {{s-ppo}} {{s-bef|before=Judith H. Hope}} {{s-ttl|title=Chairman of the [[New York State Democratic Committee]]|years=2001–2006}} {{s-aft|after=June O'Neill/David Pollak}} {{s-end}} {{New York State Democratic Committee}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Farrell, Herman D. Jr.}} [[Category:1932 births]] [[Category:2018 deaths]] [[Category:People from Manhattan]] [[Category:African-American state legislators in New York (state)]] [[Category:Members of the New York State Assembly]] [[Category:New York (state) Democrats]] [[Category:Politicians from New York City]] [[Category:United States presidential electors, 2000]] [[Category:United States presidential electors, 2004]] [[Category:21st-century American politicians]] [[Category:Deaths from heart failure]] [[Category:New York State Democratic Committee]]

revision.text:
{{Use Canadian English|date=June 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2013}} {{Infobox politician | name = Hugh F. Hanrahan | image = | caption = | office = [[Canadians|Canadian]] [[Member of Parliament]] | term_start = 1993 | term_end = 1997 | predecessor = [[Scott Thorkelson]] | successor = [[Rahim Jaffer]] | constituency = [[Edmonton—Strathcona]] | majority = | birth_date = {{birth date|df=yes|1947|01|16}} | birth_place = [[Antigonish, Nova Scotia]], Canada | death_date = {{death date and age|df=yes|1999|5|19|1947|01|16}} | death_place = | party = [[Reform Party of Canada]] | relations = | spouse = Dianne Hanrahan (m. 1970) | children = Margaret Hanrahan | residence = | occupation = Author and teacher | religion = Catholic | signature = | website = | footnotes = <ref name=CPG1996>{{cite book | title=Canadian Parliamentary Guide | year=1996 | first1=Kathryn | last1=O'Handley | first2=Caroline | last2=Sutherland | publisher=Gale Canada }}</ref> }}
'''Hugh F. Hanrahan''' (16 January 1947 – 19 May 1999) was a member of the [[House of Commons of Canada]] for the [[Edmonton—Strathcona]] [[electoral district]] from 1993 to 1997. His career has been in [[education]] and [[writing]].
Hanrahan was born in [[Antigonish, Nova Scotia]], where he would study arts and education at [[St. Francis Xavier University]], then moved to Ottawa to obtain a master's degree in education at the [[University of Ottawa]]. He moved to Edmonton where he was a teacher in the city's Roman Catholic school system for more than two decades.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.parl.gc.ca/36/1/parlbus/chambus/house/debates/240_1999-06-08/han240_1515-e.htm | work=House of Commons Debates (Hansard) | date=8 June 1999 | title=The Late Hugh Hanrahan | accessdate=23 May 2010}}</ref>
He was elected to the [[35th Canadian Parliament]] in the [[Canadian federal election, 1993|1993 federal election]] for the [[Reform Party of Canada|Reform party]]. He left Canadian politics for health reasons after his term in Parliament ended with the [[Canadian federal election, 1997|1997 federal election]]. In May 1999, Hanrahan died suddenly following an acute stomach infection. He was survived by his wife and daughter.<ref>{{cite news | title=Teacher, former MP mourned | publisher=''[[Edmonton Journal]]'' | date=25 May 1999 | page=B2 | first=Johanna | last=Kowal }}</ref>
==References== <references />
==External links== *{{Canadian Parliament links|ID=4526}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Hanrahan, Hugh}} [[Category:1947 births]] [[Category:1999 deaths]] [[Category:Canadian people of Irish descent]] [[Category:Canadian Roman Catholics]] [[Category:Deaths from infectious disease]] [[Category:Members of the House of Commons of Canada from Alberta]] [[Category:People from Antigonish, Nova Scotia]] [[Category:Reform Party of Canada MPs]] [[Category:St. Francis Xavier University alumni]] [[Category:University of Ottawa alumni]] [[Category:Politicians from Edmonton]]

The '''Human Connectome Project''' ('''HCP''') is a five-year project sponsored by sixteen components of the [[National Institutes of Health]], split between two consortia of research institutions. The project was launched in July 2009<ref name = "NIH_2009-07-15" /> as the first of three Grand Challenges of the NIH's Blueprint for Neuroscience Research.<ref name = "NIH_Blueprint" /> On September 15, 2010, the NIH announced that it would award two grants: $30 million over five years to a consortium led by [[Washington University in Saint Louis]] and the [[University of Minnesota]], with strong contributions from Oxford University (FMRIB) and $8.5 million over three years to a consortium led by [[Harvard University]], [[Massachusetts General Hospital]] and the [[University of California Los Angeles]].<ref name = "NIH_2010-09-15" />
The goal of the Human Connectome Project is to build a "network map" ([[connectome]]) that will shed light on the anatomical and functional connectivity within the healthy [[human brain]], as well as to produce a body of data that will facilitate research into [[brain disorder]]s such as [[dyslexia]], [[autism]], [[Alzheimer's disease]], and [[schizophrenia]].<ref name = "BBC_2013-02-16" /><ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1038/nature.2016.20285 |title=Human brain mapped in unprecedented detail |journal=Nature |year=2016 |last1=Geddes |first1=Linda }}</ref>
As of November 16, 2018, the project has yet to be officially declared complete.
==WU-Minn-Oxford consortium== The WU-Minn-Oxford consortium developed improved MRI instrumentation, image acquisition and image analysis methods for mapping the connectivity in the human brain at spatial resolutions significantly better than previously available; using these methods, WI-Minn-Oxford consortium collected a large amount of MRI and behavioral data on 1,200 healthy adults — twin pairs and their siblings from 300 families - using a special 3 Tesla MRI instrument. In addition, it scanned 184 subjects from this pool at 7 Tesla, with higher spatial resolution. The data are being analyzed to show the anatomical and functional connections between parts of the brain for each individual, and will be related to behavioral test data. Comparing the [[connectome]]s and genetic data of genetically [[identical twins]] with fraternal twins will reveal the relative contributions of genes and environment in shaping brain circuitry and pinpoint relevant [[genetic variation]]. The maps will also shed light on how brain networks are organized.
Using a combination of [[Minimally-invasive procedures#Non-invasive procedure|non-invasive]] [[imaging technologies]], including [[resting state fMRI|resting-state fMRI]] and task-based [[functional MRI]], [[Magnetoencephalography|MEG]] and [[EEG]], and [[diffusion MRI]], the WU-Minn will be mapping [[connectome]]s at the macro scale — [[Brain mapping|mapping large brain systems]] that can be divided into anatomically and functionally distinct areas, rather than mapping individual [[neuron]]s.
Dozens of investigators and researchers from nine institutions have contributed to this project. Research institutions include: Washington University in Saint Louis, the Center for Magnetic Resonance Research at the [[University of Minnesota]], [[Oxford University]], [[Saint Louis University]], [[Indiana University]], [[D'Annunzio University of Chieti–Pescara]], [[Ernst Strungmann Institute]], [[Warwick University]], Advanced MRI Technologies, and the [[University of California at Berkeley]].<ref>{{cite web|title=$40 Million Awarded to Trace Human Brain’s Connections|url=http://www.nimh.nih.gov:80/science-news/2010/40-million-awarded-to-trace-human-brains-connections.shtml|publisher=NIMH|accessdate=March 12, 2018|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120110052518/http://www.nimh.nih.gov:80/science-news/2010/40-million-awarded-to-trace-human-brains-connections.shtml|archivedate=January 10, 2012|date=September 15, 2010}}</ref>
The data that results from this research is being made publicly available in an open-source web-accessible neuroinformatics platform.<ref>https://www.humanconnectome.org/</ref><ref>https://db.humanconnectome.org</ref>
==MGH/Harvard-UCLA consortium== The MGH/Harvard-UCLA consortium will focus on optimizing MRI technology for imaging the brain’s structural connections using [[diffusion MRI]], with a goal of increasing [[spatial resolution]], quality, and speed. Diffusion MRI, employed in both projects, maps the brain's fibrous long distance connections by tracking the motion of water. Water [[diffusion]] patterns in different types of cells allow the detection of different types of tissues. Using this imaging method, the long extensions of neurons, called [[white matter]], can be seen in sharp relief.<ref name = "UCLA_LNI" /><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Fan|first=Qiuyun|last2=Witzel|first2=Thomas|last3=Nummenmaa|first3=Aapo|last4=Van Dijk|first4=Koene R. A.|last5=Van Horn|first5=John D.|last6=Drews|first6=Michelle K.|last7=Somerville|first7=Leah H.|last8=Sheridan|first8=Margaret A.|last9=Santillana|first9=Rosario M.|date=2016-01-01|title=MGH-USC Human Connectome Project datasets with ultra-high b-value diffusion MRI|journal=NeuroImage|volume=124|issue=Pt B|pages=1108–1114|doi=10.1016/j.neuroimage.2015.08.075|issn=1095-9572|pmc=4651764|pmid=26364861}}</ref>
The new scanner built at the MGH [[Martinos Center]] for this project is "4 to 8 times as powerful as conventional systems, enabling imaging of human [[neuroanatomy]] with greater sensitivity than was previously possible."<ref name = "NIH_2010-09-15" /> The scanner has a maximum gradient strength of 300 mT/m and a [[slew rate]] of 200 [[Tesla (unit)|T]]/m/s, with b-values tested up to 20,000. For comparison, a standard gradient is 45 mT/m, with a b-value of 700.<ref>Improving SNR in high b-value diffusion imaging using Gmax = 300 mT/m human gradients, Proc. Intl. Soc. Mag. Reson. Med. 20 (2012) 2738</ref><ref>http://www.nmr.mgh.harvard.edu/martinos/aboutUs/facilities.php{{full citation needed|date=May 2018}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Fan|first=Qiuyun|last2=Nummenmaa|first2=Aapo|last3=Witzel|first3=Thomas|last4=Zanzonico|first4=Roberta|last5=Keil|first5=Boris|last6=Cauley|first6=Stephen|last7=Polimeni|first7=Jonathan R.|last8=Tisdall|first8=Dylan|last9=Van Dijk|first9=Koene R. A.|date=2014-11-21|title=Investigating the capability to resolve complex white matter structures with high b-value diffusion magnetic resonance imaging on the MGH-USC Connectom scanner|journal=Brain Connectivity|volume=4|issue=9|pages=718–726|doi=10.1089/brain.2014.0305|issn=2158-0022|pmc=4238244|pmid=25287963|via=}}</ref>
==Behavioral testing and measurement== To understand the relationship between brain connectivity and behavior better, the Human Connectome Project will use a reliable and well-validated battery of measures that assess a wide range of human functions. The core of its battery is the tools and methods developed by the [[NIH Toolbox]] for Assessment of Neurological and Behavioral function.<ref>http://humanconnectome.org/about/project/behavioral-testing.html, Retrieved 2013-03-08</ref>
== Research == The Human Connectome Project has grown into a large group of research teams. These teams make use of the style of brain scanning developed by the Project.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1038/nn.4361 |pmid=27571196 |title=The Human Connectome Project's neuroimaging approach |journal=Nature Neuroscience |volume=19 |issue=9 |pages=1175–87 |year=2016 |last1=Glasser |first1=Matthew F |last2=Smith |first2=Stephen M |last3=Marcus |first3=Daniel S |last4=Andersson |first4=Jesper L R |last5=Auerbach |first5=Edward J |last6=Behrens |first6=Timothy E J |last7=Coalson |first7=Timothy S |last8=Harms |first8=Michael P |last9=Jenkinson |first9=Mark |last10=Moeller |first10=Steen |last11=Robinson |first11=Emma C |last12=Sotiropoulos |first12=Stamatios N |last13=Xu |first13=Junqian |last14=Yacoub |first14=Essa |last15=Ugurbil |first15=Kamil |last16=Van Essen |first16=David C }}</ref> The studies usually include using large groups of participants, scanning many angles of participants' brains, and carefully documenting the location of the structures in each participant's brain.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.humanconnectome.org/|title=Connectome - Homepage|last=UpAndRunning|website=www.humanconnectome.org|language=en|access-date=2017-11-28}}</ref> Studies affiliated with the Human Connectome Project are currently cataloged by the Connectome Coordination Facility. The studies fall into three categories: Healthy Adult Connectomes, Lifespan Connectome Data, and Connectomes Related to Human Disease. Under each of these categories are research groups working on specific questions.
=== Healthy Adult Connectomes === <ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.humanconnectome.org/study/hcp-young-adult|title=HCP Young Adult - Connectome - Publications|last=UpAndRunning|website=www.humanconnectome.org|language=en|access-date=2017-11-29}}</ref> The Human Connectome Project Young Adult study made data on the brain connections of 1100 healthy young adults available to the scientific community.<ref>http://www.humanconnectome.org/about/publications-using-hcp-data.php</ref> Scientists have used data from the study to support theories about which areas of the brain communicate with one another.<ref name=pmid28231395>{{cite journal |doi=10.1111/ejn.13544 |pmid=28231395 |title=Functional connectivity in amygdalar-sensory/(pre)motor networks at rest: New evidence from the Human Connectome Project |journal=European Journal of Neuroscience |volume=45 |issue=9 |pages=1224–1229 |year=2017 |last1=Toschi |first1=Nicola |last2=Duggento |first2=Andrea |last3=Passamonti |first3=Luca }}</ref> For example, one study used data from the project to show that the [[amygdala]], a part of the brain essential for emotional processing, is connected to the parts of the brain that receive information from the senses and plan movement.<ref name=pmid27744495>{{cite journal |doi=10.1007/s11682-016-9642-2 |pmid=27744495 |title=White matter integrity in brain networks relevant to anxiety and depression: Evidence from the human connectome project dataset |journal=Brain Imaging and Behavior |volume=11 |issue=6 |pages=1604–1615 |year=2016 |last1=De Witte |first1=Nele A. J |last2=Mueller |first2=Sven C }}</ref> Another study showed that healthy individuals who had a high tendency to experience anxious or depressed mood had fewer connections between the amygdala and a number of brain areas related to attention.
=== Lifespan Connectome Data === <ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.humanconnectome.org/lifespan-studies|title=Connectome - HCP Lifespan Studies|last=UpAndRunning|website=www.humanconnectome.org|language=en|access-date=2017-12-13}}</ref> There are currently four research groups collecting data on connections in the brains of populations other than young adults. The purpose of these groups is to determine ordinary brain connectivity during infancy, childhood, adolescence, and aging. Scientists will use the data from these research groups in the same manner in which they have used data from the Human Connectome Project Young Adult study.
=== Connectomes Related to Human Disease === <ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.humanconnectome.org/disease-studies|title=Connectome - Human Connectome Studies Related To Disease|last=UpAndRunning|website=www.humanconnectome.org|language=en|access-date=2017-12-13}}</ref> Fourteen research groups investigate how connections in the brain change during the course of a particular disease. Four of the groups focus on [[Alzheimer's Disease]] or [[dementia]]. Alzheimer's Disease and dementia are diseases that begin during aging. Memory loss and cognitive impairment mark the progression of these diseases. While scientists consider Alzheimer's Disease to be a disease with a specific cause, dementia actually describes symptoms which could be attributed to a number of causes. Two other research groups investigate how diseases that disrupt vision change connectivity in the brain. Another four of the research groups focus on [[anxiety disorders]] and [[Major Depressive Disorder]], psychological disorders that result in abnormal emotional regulation. Two more of the research groups focus on the effects of [[psychosis]], a symptom of some psychological disorders in which an individual perceives reality differently than others do. One of the teams researches [[epilepsy]], a disease characterized by seizures. Finally, one research team is documenting the brain connections of the [[Amish]] people, a religious and ethnic group that has high rates of some [[psychological disorders]].
Although theories have been put forth about the way brain connections change in the diseases under investigation, many of these theories have been supported by data from healthy populations.<ref name=pmid27744495/> For example, an analysis of the brains of healthy individuals supported the theory that individuals with anxiety disorders and depression have less connectivity between their emotional centers and the areas that govern attention. By collecting data specifically from individuals with these diseases, researchers hope to have a more certain idea of how brain connections in these individuals change over time.
== Status == As of May 30th, 2018, the project has yet to be officially declared complete.
== Useful links == [https://wiki.humanconnectome.org/ HCP wiki] - Human Connectome Project wiki
[https://fsl.fmrib.ox.ac.uk/fsl/fslwiki/FIX ICA-FIX] - Documentation on ICA-FIX algorithm used on resting state fMRI data<ref name=pmid23702415>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/j.neuroimage.2013.05.039 {{Multiple issues| {{one source|date=July 2016}} {{more footnotes|date=July 2016}} }}
{{Humanism|Organizations = Kurdish Humanist Association|Kurdish Humanist Association = }} '''''Humanist Manifesto''''' is the title of three [[manifesto]]s laying out a [[Humanism|Humanist]] worldview. They are the original ''[[Humanist Manifesto I|Humanist Manifesto]]'' (1933, often referred to as Humanist Manifesto I), the ''[[Humanist Manifesto II]]'' (1973), and ''[[Humanism and Its Aspirations]]'' (2003, a.k.a. ''[http://americanhumanist.org/humanism/humanist_manifesto_iii Humanist Manifesto III]''). The Manifesto originally arose from [[religious Humanism]], though [[secular Humanism|secular Humanists]] also signed.
The central theme of all three ''manifestos'' is the elaboration of a [[philosophy]] and value system which does not necessarily include belief in any personal deity or "higher power", although the three differ considerably in their tone, form, and ambition. Each has been signed at its launch by various prominent members of [[academia]] and others who are in general agreement with its principles.
In addition, there is a similar document entitled ''[[A Secular Humanist Declaration]]'' published in 1980 by the [[Council for Secular Humanism]].
==Humanist Manifesto I== {{unreferenced section|date=July 2016}} {{main article|Humanist Manifesto I}} The first manifesto, entitled simply ''A Humanist Manifesto'', was written in 1933 primarily by [[Roy Wood Sellars]] and [[Raymond Bragg]] and was published with 34 signatories including philosopher [[John Dewey]]. Unlike the later ones, the first Manifesto talked of a new "[[religion]]", and referred to Humanism as a religious movement to transcend and replace previous religions that were based on allegations of supernatural revelation. The document outlines a fifteen-point belief system, which, in addition to a secular outlook, opposes "acquisitive and profit-motivated society" and outlines a worldwide egalitarian society based on voluntary mutual cooperation, language which was considerably softened by the Humanists' board, owners of the document, twenty years later.
The title "A Humanist Manifesto"—rather than "The Humanist Manifesto"—was intentional, predictive of later Manifestos to follow, as indeed has been the case. Unlike the creeds of major organized religions, the setting out of Humanist ideals in these Manifestos is an ongoing process. Indeed, in some communities of Humanists the compilation of personal Manifestos is actively encouraged, and throughout the Humanist movement it is accepted that the Humanist Manifestos are not permanent or authoritative dogmas but are to be subject to ongoing critique.
==Humanist Manifesto II== {{main article|Humanist Manifesto II}} {{refimprove section|date=July 2016}} The second Manifesto was written in 1973 by [[Paul Kurtz]] and [[Edwin H. Wilson]], and was intended to update and replace the previous one. It begins with a statement that the excesses of [[Nazism]] and [[World War II]] had made the first seem "far too optimistic", and indicated a more hardheaded and realistic approach in its seventeen-point statement, which was much longer and more elaborate than the previous version. Nevertheless, much of the unbridled optimism of the first remained, with hopes stated that war would become obsolete and poverty would be eliminated.
Many of the proposals in the document, such as opposition to [[racism]] and [[weapons of mass destruction]] and support of strong [[human rights]], are fairly uncontroversial, and its prescriptions that [[divorce]] and [[birth control]] should be legal and that [[technology]] can improve life are widely accepted today in much of the [[Western world]].{{Citation needed|date=May 2012}} Furthermore, its proposal of an [[international court]] has [[International Court of Justice|since been implemented]]. However, in addition to its rejection of supernaturalism, various controversial stances are strongly supported, notably the right to [[abortion]].
Initially published with a small number of signatures, the document was circulated and gained thousands more, and indeed the [[American Humanist Association|AHA]] website encourages visitors to add their own name. A provision at the end noted that signators do "not necessarily endors[e] every detail" of the document.
Among the oft-quoted lines from this 1973 Manifesto are, "No deity will save us; we must save ourselves," and "We are responsible for what we are and for what we will be," both of which may present difficulties for members of certain Christian, Jewish, and Muslim sects, or other believers in doctrines of submission to the will of an all-powerful God.
Expanding upon the role the public education establishment should play to bring about the goals described in the Humanist Manifesto II, [[John Dunphy]] wrote: "I am convinced that the battle for humankind's future must be waged and won in the public school classroom by teachers that correctly perceive their role as proselytizers of a new faith: a religion of humanity that recognizes and respects the spark of what theologians call divinity in every human being...The classroom must and will become an arena of conflict between the old and new -- the rotting corpse of Christianity, together with all its adjacent evils and misery, and the new faith of humanism, resplendent with the promise of a world in which the never-realized Christian ideal of 'love thy neighbor' will finally be achieved." <ref>Dunphy, J., A Religion for a New Age, The Humanist, January–February 1983</ref>
==Humanist Manifesto III== {{see main|Humanism and Its Aspirations}}
''Humanism and Its Aspirations'', subtitled ''Humanist Manifesto III, a successor to the Humanist Manifesto of 1933'', was published in 2003 by the [[American Humanist Association | AHA]], and was written by committee. Signatories included 21 Nobel laureates. The new document is the successor to the previous ones, and the name "Humanist Manifesto" is the property of the American Humanist Association.
The newest manifesto is deliberately much shorter, listing seven primary themes, which echo those from its predecessors [http://www.americanhumanist.org/humanism/Humanist_Manifesto_III] :
* Knowledge of the world is derived by observation, experimentation, and rational analysis. (See [[empiricism]].) * Humans are an integral part of nature, the result of [[evolution]]ary change, an unguided process. * [[ethics|Ethical]] values are derived from human need and interest as tested by experience. (See [[ethical naturalism]].) * Life’s fulfillment emerges from individual participation in the service of humane ideals. * Humans are social by nature and find meaning in relationships. * Working to benefit society maximizes individual happiness.
==Other Manifestos for Humanism== {{unreferenced section|date=July 2016}} Aside from the official Humanist Manifestos of the [[American Humanist Association]] ("AHA"), there have been other similar documents. "Humanist Manifesto" is a [[trademark]] of the AHA. Formulation of new statements in emulation of the three Humanist Manifestos is encouraged, and examples follow.
===A Secular Humanist Declaration=== {{main article|A Secular Humanist Declaration}} In 1980, the [[Council for Secular Humanism]], founded by [[Paul Kurtz]], which is typically more detailed in its discussions regarding the function of Humanism than the AHA, published what is in effect its manifesto, entitled ''[[A Secular Humanist Declaration]]''. It has as its main points:
# Free Inquiry # Separation of Church and State # The Ideal of Freedom # Ethics Based on Critical Intelligence # Moral Education # Religious Skepticism # Reason # Science and Technology # Evolution # Education
'''A Secular Humanist Declaration''' was an argument for and statement of support for [[democracy|democratic]] [[secular humanism]]. The document was issued in 1980 by the Council for Democratic and Secular Humanism ("CODESH"), now the [[Council for Secular Humanism]] ("CSH"). Compiled by [[Paul Kurtz]], it is largely a restatement of the content of the [[American Humanist Association]]'s 1973 [[Humanist Manifesto II]], of which he was co-author with [[Edwin H. Wilson]]. Both Wilson and Kurtz had served as editors of ''[[The Humanist]]'', from which Kurtz departed in 1979 and thereafter set about establishing his own movement and his own periodical. His Secular Humanist Declaration was the starting point for these enterprises.
===Humanist Manifesto 2000=== ''Humanist Manifesto 2000: A Call for New Planetary Humanism'' is a book by [[Paul Kurtz]] published in 2000. It differs from the other three in that it is a full-length book rather than essay-length, and was published not by the American Humanist Association but by the [[Council for Secular Humanism]]. In it, Kurtz argues for many of the points already formulated in Humanist Manifesto 2, of which he had been co-author in 1973.
===Amsterdam Declaration=== {{main article|Amsterdam Declaration}}
The '''Amsterdam Declaration 2002''' is a statement of the fundamental principles of modern [[Humanism]] passed unanimously by the General Assembly of the [[International Humanist and Ethical Union]] (IHEU) at the 50th anniversary World Humanist Congress in 2002. According to the IHEU, the declaration "is the official statement of World Humanism."
It is officially supported by all member organisations of the IHEU including:
*[[American Humanist Association]] *[[British Humanist Association]] *[[Humanist Canada]] *[[Council of Australian Humanist Societies]] *[[Council for Secular Humanism]] *[[Gay and Lesbian Humanist Association]] *[[Human-Etisk Forbund]], the Norwegian Humanist Association *[[Humanist Association of Ireland]] *[[Indian Humanist Union]] *[[Philippine Atheists and Agnostics Society (PATAS)]]
A complete list of signatories can be found on the [[IHEU]] page (see references).
This declaration makes exclusive use of capitalized ''Humanist'' and ''Humanism'', which is consistent with IHEU's general practice and recommendations for promoting a unified Humanist identity.{{ref|Webbs}}{{full citation needed|date=July 2016}} To further promote Humanist identity, these words are also free of any adjectives, as recommended by prominent members of IHEU.{{ref|Blackham}}{{full citation needed|date=July 2016}} Such usage is not universal among IHEU member organizations, though most of them do observe these conventions.
==References== <references/>
==External links==
===Manifestos=== * ''[https://americanhumanist.org/what-is-humanism/manifesto1/ Humanist Manifesto I]'' (1933) * ''[https://web.archive.org/web/20130628200009/http://iheu.org/content/amsterdam-declaration-1952 Amsterdam Declaration 1952]'' * ''[https://americanhumanist.org/what-is-humanism/manifesto2/ Humanist Manifesto II]'' (1973) * ''[https://web.archive.org/web/20080817084107/http://www.secularhumanism.org/index.php?section=main&page=declaration A Secular Humanist Declaration]'' (1980) * ''[https://web.archive.org/web/20120926052944/http://www.iheu.org/node/2140 A Declaration of Interdependence]''(1988) * ''[https://web.archive.org/web/20081026003615/http://www.iheu.org/node/178 IEHU Minimum Statement on Humanism]'' (1996) * ''[http://mhec.humanists.net/HUMNISM.HTM Humanism: Why, What, and What For, In 882 Words]'' (1996) * ''[http://www.secularhumanism.org/index.php?section=main&page=manifesto Humanist Manifesto 2000: A Call For A New Planetary Humanism]'' * ''[http://www.secularhumanism.org/index.php?section=main&page=promise The Promise of Manifesto 2000]'' * ''[http://www.iheu.org/adamdecl.htm Amsterdam Declaration 2002]'' * ''[https://americanhumanist.org/what-is-humanism/manifesto3/ Humanism and Its Aspirations: Humanist Manifesto III]'' (2003) ** [http://aha-files.s3.amazonaws.com/63/238/HumanismandItsAspirations.pdf PDF Printer Friendly Version] * ''[https://web.archive.org/web/20120629040523/http://www.humanisme-contemporain.com/ Manifeste pour un humanisme contemporain ]'' (2012)
===Miscellaneous=== * [http://infidels.org/library/modern/edwin_wilson/manifesto/ The Genesis of a Humanist Manifesto] by [[Edwin H. Wilson]] * [http://huumanists.org/ HUUmanists, an association of Unitarian Universalist Humanists] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20100619130831/http://americanhumanist.org/Who_We_Are/About_Humanism/Humanist_Manifesto_III/Notable_Signers Notable signers]

{{Infobox medical condition (new) | name = Intracerebral hemorrhage | image = Intracerebral hemorrage (CT scan).jpg | caption = [[CT scan]] of a spontaneous intracerebral bleed, leaking into the [[lateral ventricles]] | field = [[Neurosurgery]] | synonyms = Cerebral haemorrhage, cerebral hemorrhage, intra-axial hemorrhage, cerebral hematoma, cerebral bleed | symptoms = [[Headache]], one-sided weakness, vomiting, seizures, [[decreased level of consciousness]], [[neck stiffness]], [[fever]]<ref name=Hem2015/><ref name=Ca2012/> | complications = | onset = | duration = | types = | causes = [[Brain trauma]], [[brain aneurysm|aneurysm]]s, [[arteriovenous malformation]]s, [[brain tumors]]<ref name=Hem2015/> | risks = [[High blood pressure]], [[amyloidosis]], [[alcoholism]], [[low cholesterol]], [[blood thinners]], [[cocaine]]<ref name=Ca2012/> | diagnosis = [[CT scan]]<ref name=Hem2015/> | differential = [[Ischemic stroke]]<ref name=Hem2015/> | prevention = | treatment = [[Blood pressure]] control, surgery, [[ventricular drain]] <ref name=Hem2015/> | medication = | prognosis = 20% good outcome<ref name=Ca2012/> | frequency = 2.5 per 10,000 people a year<ref name=Ca2012/> | deaths = 44% die within one month<ref name=Ca2012/> }} <!-- Definition and symptoms --> '''Intracerebral hemorrhage''' ('''ICH'''), also known as '''cerebral bleed''', is a type of [[intracranial bleed]] that occurs within the [[intraparenchymal bleed|brain tissue]] or [[intraventricular hemorrhages|ventricles]].<ref>{{cite book|last1=Naidich|first1=Thomas P.|last2=Castillo|first2=Mauricio|last3=Cha|first3=Soonmee|last4=Smirniotopoulos|first4=James G.|title=Imaging of the Brain, Expert Radiology Series,1: Imaging of the Brain|date=2012|publisher=Elsevier Health Sciences|isbn=978-1416050094|page=387|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=TUfZSKldJRwC&pg=PA387|language=en|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161002094230/https://books.google.com/books?id=TUfZSKldJRwC&pg=PA387|archivedate=2016-10-02|df=}}</ref> Symptoms can include [[headache]], one-sided weakness, vomiting, seizures, [[decreased level of consciousness]], and [[neck stiffness]].<ref name=Ca2012/> Often symptoms get worse over time.<ref name=Hem2015/> [[Fever]] is also common.<ref name=Hem2015/> In many cases bleeding is present in both the brain tissue and the ventricles.<ref name=Hem2015/>
<!-- Cause and diagnosis --> Causes include [[brain trauma]], [[brain aneurysm|aneurysm]]s, [[arteriovenous malformation]]s, and [[brain tumors]].<ref name=Hem2015/> The largest risk factors for spontaneous bleeding are [[high blood pressure]] and [[amyloidosis]].<ref name=Ca2012/> Other risk factors include [[alcoholism]], [[low cholesterol]], [[blood thinners]], and [[cocaine]] use.<ref name=Ca2012/> Diagnosis is typically by [[CT scan]].<ref name=Hem2015/> Other conditions that may present similarly include [[ischemic stroke]].<ref name=Hem2015>{{cite journal|last1=Hemphill JC|first1=3rd|last2=Greenberg|first2=SM|last3=Anderson|first3=CS|last4=Becker|first4=K|last5=Bendok|first5=BR|last6=Cushman|first6=M|last7=Fung|first7=GL|last8=Goldstein|first8=JN|last9=Macdonald|first9=RL|last10=Mitchell|first10=PH|last11=Scott|first11=PA|last12=Selim|first12=MH|last13=Woo|first13=D|last14=American Heart Association Stroke|first14=Council|last15=Council on Cardiovascular and Stroke|first15=Nursing|last16=Council on Clinical|first16=Cardiology|title=Guidelines for the Management of Spontaneous Intracerebral Hemorrhage: A Guideline for Healthcare Professionals From the American Heart Association/American Stroke Association|journal=Stroke: A Journal of Cerebral Circulation|date=July 2015|volume=46|issue=7|pages=2032–60|pmid=26022637|doi=10.1161/str.0000000000000069|pmc=4462131}}</ref>
<!-- Prevention and treatment --> Treatment should typically be carried out in an [[intensive care unit]].<ref name=Hem2015/> Guidelines recommended decreasing the [[blood pressure]] to a [[systolic blood pressure|systolic]] of 140 mmHg.<ref name=Hem2015/><ref>{{cite journal |last1=Ko |first1=SB |last2=Yoon |first2=BW |title=Blood Pressure Management for Acute Ischemic and Hemorrhagic Stroke: The Evidence |journal=Seminars in Respiratory and Critical Care Medicine |date=December 2017 |volume=38 |issue=6 |pages=718–725 |doi=10.1055/s-0037-1608777 |pmid=29262429}}</ref> Blood thinners should be reversed if possible and [[blood sugar]] kept in the normal range.<ref name=Hem2015/> Surgery to place a [[ventricular drain]] may be used to treat [[hydrocephalus]] but [[corticosteroids]] should not be used.<ref name=Hem2015/> Surgery to remove the blood is useful in certain cases.<ref name=Hem2015/>
<!-- Epidemiology --> Cerebral bleeding affects about 2.5 per 10,000 people each year.<ref name=Ca2012/> It occurs more often in males and older people.<ref name=Ca2012/> About 44% of those affected die within a month.<ref name=Ca2012/> A good outcome occurs in about 20% of those affected.<ref name=Ca2012>{{cite journal|last1=Caceres|first1=JA|last2=Goldstein|first2=JN|title=Intracranial hemorrhage|journal=Emergency Medicine Clinics of North America|date=August 2012|volume=30|issue=3|pages=771–94|pmid=22974648|doi=10.1016/j.emc.2012.06.003|pmc=3443867}}</ref> [[Stroke]]s were first divided into their two major types, bleeding and insufficient blood flow, in 1823.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Hennerici|first1=Michael|title=Imaging in Stroke|date=2003|publisher=Remedica|isbn=9781901346251|page=1|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=RG6be-FhMxEC&pg=PA1|language=en|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161002095126/https://books.google.com/books?id=RG6be-FhMxEC&pg=PA1|archivedate=2016-10-02|df=}}</ref>
==Signs and symptoms== People with intracerebral bleeding have symptoms that correspond to the functions controlled by the area of the brain that is damaged by the bleed.<ref name="Vinas and Pilistis">Vinas FC and Pilitsis J. 2006. [http://www.emedicine.com/med/topic2888.htm "Penetrating Head Trauma."] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20050913061516/http://www.emedicine.com/med/topic2888.htm |date=2005-09-13 }} Emedicine.com.</ref> Other symptoms include those that indicate a rise in [[intracranial pressure]] caused by a large mass putting pressure on the brain.<ref name="Vinas and Pilistis"/> Intracerebral bleeds are often misdiagnosed as [[subarachnoid hemorrhage]]s due to the similarity in symptoms and signs. A severe headache followed by vomiting is one of the more common symptoms of intracerebral hemorrhage. Another common symptom is a patient can collapse. Some people may experience continuous bleeding from the ear. Some patients may also go into a coma before the bleed is noticed.
==Causes== [[File:Posterior fossa hemorrhage.jpg|thumb|right|Axial CT scan showing hemorrhage in the [[Posterior cranial fossa|posterior fossa]]<ref name="Yadav07">{{cite journal|year=2007|title=Endoscopic management of hypertensive intraventricular haemorrhage with obstructive hydrocephalus|url=http://www.biomedcentral.com/1471-2377/7/1|journal=BMC Neurol|volume=7|pages=1|doi=10.1186/1471-2377-7-1|pmc=1780056|pmid=17204141|vauthors=Yadav YR, Mukerji G, Shenoy R, Basoor A, Jain G, Nelson A|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080605033627/http://www.biomedcentral.com/1471-2377/7/1|archivedate=2008-06-05|df=}}</ref>]] Intracerebral bleeds are the second most common cause of [[stroke]], accounting for 10% of hospital admissions for stroke.<ref name="pmid23239837">{{cite journal |vauthors=Go AS, Mozaffarian D, Roger VL |title=Heart disease and stroke statistics--2013 update: a report from the American Heart Association |journal=Circulation |volume=127 |issue=1 |pages=e6–e245 |date=January 2013 |pmid=23239837 |pmc=5408511 |doi=10.1161/CIR.0b013e31828124ad |url=|display-authors=etal}}</ref> [[Hypertension|High blood pressure]] raises the risks of spontaneous intracerebral hemorrhage by two to six times.<ref name="Yadav07"/> More common in adults than in children, intraparenchymal bleeds are usually due to [[penetrating head trauma]], but can also be due to depressed [[skull fracture]]s. Acceleration-deceleration trauma,<ref name="McCaffrey">McCaffrey P. 2001. [http://www.csuchico.edu/~pmccaff/syllabi/SPPA336/336unit11.html "The Neuroscience on the Web Series: CMSD 336 Neuropathologies of Language and Cognition."] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20051125040437/http://www.csuchico.edu/~pmccaff/syllabi/SPPA336/336unit11.html |date=2005-11-25 }} California State University, Chico. Retrieved on June 19, 2007.</ref><ref name="Orlando Regional Healthcare">Orlando Regional Healthcare, Education and Development. 2004. [http://www.orlandoregional.org/pdf%20folder/overview%20adult%20brain%20injury.pdf "Overview of Adult Traumatic Brain Injuries."] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080227162001/http://www.orlandoregional.org/pdf%20folder/overview%20adult%20brain%20injury.pdf |date=2008-02-27 }} Retrieved on 2008-01-16.</ref><ref name="Shepherd">Shepherd S. 2004. [http://www.emedicine.com/med/topic2820.htm "Head Trauma."] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20051026012843/http://www.emedicine.com/med/topic2820.htm |date=2005-10-26 }} Emedicine.com. Retrieved on June 19, 2007.</ref> rupture of an [[aneurysm]] or [[arteriovenous malformation]] (AVM), and bleeding within a [[tumor]] are additional causes. Amyloid angiopathy is a not uncommon cause of intracerebral hemorrhage in patients over the age of 55. A very small proportion is due to [[cerebral venous sinus thrombosis]].
Risk factors for ICH include:<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Feldmann | first1 = Edward | last2 = Broderick | first2 = Joseph P. | last3 = Kernan | first3 = Walter N. | last4 = Viscoli | first4 = Catherine M. | last5 = Brass | first5 = Lawrence M. | last6 = Brott | first6 = Thomas | last7 = Morgenstern | first7 = Lewis B. | last8 = Lee Wilterdink | first8 = Janet | last9 = Horwitz | first9 = Ralph I. | year = 2005 | title = Major Risk Factors for Intracerebral Hamorrhage in the Young Are Modifiable | url = http://stroke.ahajournals.org/cgi/content/abstract/36/9/1881 | journal = Stroke | volume = 36 | issue = 9| pages = 1881–5 | doi = 10.1161/01.str.0000177480.62341.6b | pmid = 16081867 | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20090305032934/http://stroke.ahajournals.org/cgi/content/abstract/36/9/1881 | archivedate = 2009-03-05 | df = }}</ref> * [[Hypertension]] (high blood pressure) * [[Diabetes mellitus]] * [[Menopause]] * [[Cigarette smoking]] * Excessive [[alcohol consumption]] * Severe [[migraine]]
Traumautic intracerebral hematomas are divided into acute and delayed. Acute intracerebral hematomas occur at the time of the injury while delayed intracerebral hematomas have been reported from as early as 6 hours post injury to as long as several weeks.
==Diagnosis== [[File:Intracerebral hemorrhage.jpg|thumb|Spontaneous ICH with [[hydrocephalus]] on CT scan<ref name="Yadav07"/>]] Both [[computed tomography angiography]] (CTA) and [[magnetic resonance angiography]] (MRA) have been proved to be effective in diagnosing intracranial vascular malformations after ICH.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Computed tomography angiography or magnetic resonance angiography for detection of intracranial vascular malformations in patients with intracerebral haemorrhage|last = Josephson|first = Colin B|last2 = White|first2 = Philip M|last3 = Krishan|first3 = Ashma|last4 = Al-Shahi Salman|first4 = Rustum|date = 1 September 2014|journal = The Cochrane Library|doi = 10.1002/14651858.CD009372.pub2|pmid = 25177839|volume = 9|issue = 9|pages = CD009372|deadurl = no|df = }}</ref> So frequently, a CT angiogram will be performed in order to exclude a secondary cause of hemorrhage<ref name=":0">{{cite journal | vauthors = Yeung R, Ahmad T, Aviv RI, Noel de Tilly L, Fox AJ, Symons SP | year = 2009 | title = Comparison of CTA to DSA in determining the etiology of spontaneous ICH | url = | journal = Canadian Journal of Neurological Sciences | volume = 36 | issue = 2| pages = 176–180 | doi=10.1017/s0317167100006533}}</ref> or to detect a "spot sign".
[[Intraparenchymal hemorrhage]] can be recognized on [[CT scan]]s because blood appears brighter than other tissue and is separated from the inner table of the skull by brain tissue. The tissue surrounding a bleed is often less dense than the rest of the brain because of [[edema]], and therefore shows up darker on the CT scan.<ref name=":0" />
=== Location === When due to [[hypertension|high blood pressure]], intracerebral hemorrhages typically occur in the [[putamen]] (50%) or [[thalamus]] (15%), cerebrum (10-20%), cerebellum (10-13%), pons (7-15%), or elsewhere in the brainstem (1-6%).<ref>{{cite book |last=Greenberg |first=Mark S. |title= Handbook of Neurosurgery |date= 2016|isbn= 9781626232419}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Prayson|first1=Richard A.|title=Neuropathology|date=2012|publisher=Elsevier Health Sciences|isbn=978-1437709490|page=49|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=DmNSdcu14HEC&pg=PA49|language=en|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170312043001/https://books.google.com/books?id=DmNSdcu14HEC&pg=PA49|archivedate=2017-03-12|df=}}</ref>
==Treatment== Treatment depends substantially on the type of ICH. Rapid [[CT scan]] and other diagnostic measures are used to determine proper treatment, which may include both medication and surgery.
*[[Tracheal intubation]] is indicated in people with decreased level of consciousness or other risk of airway obstruction.<ref name=emedicine/> *[[Intravenous therapy#IV fluids|IV fluids]] are given to maintain [[fluid balance]], using isotonic rather than hypotonic fluids.<ref name=emedicine/>
===Medication=== *One review found that [[antihypertensive therapy]] to bring down the blood pressure in acute phases appears to improve outcomes.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Tsivgoulis|first1=G|last2=Katsanos|first2=AH|last3=Butcher|first3=KS|last4=Boviatsis|first4=E|last5=Triantafyllou|first5=N|last6=Rizos|first6=I|last7=Alexandrov|first7=AV|title=Intensive blood pressure reduction in acute intracerebral hemorrhage: A meta-analysis|journal=Neurology|date=21 October 2014|volume=83|issue=17|pages=1523–9|pmid=25239836|doi=10.1212/wnl.0000000000000917}}</ref> Other reviews found an unclear difference between intensive and less intensive blood pressure control.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Ma|first1=J|last2=Li|first2=H|last3=Liu|first3=Y|last4=You|first4=C|last5=Huang|first5=S|last6=Ma|first6=L|title=Effects of Intensive Blood Pressure Lowering on Intracerebral Hemorrhage Outcomes: A Meta-Analysis of Randomized Controlled Trials|journal=Turkish Neurosurgery|date=2015|volume=25|issue=4|pages=544–51|pmid=26242330|doi=10.5137/1019-5149.JTN.9270-13.0|doi-broken-date=2018-09-10}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|first1=Gregoire|last1=Boulouis|first2=Andrea|last2=Morotti|first3=Joshua N.|last3=Goldstein|first4=Andreas|last4=Charidimou|title=Intensive blood pressure lowering in patients with acute intracerebral haemorrhage: clinical outcomes and haemorrhage expansion. Systematic review and meta-analysis of randomised trials|journal=Journal of Neurology, Neurosurgery, and Psychiatry|date=1 April 2017|issn=1468-330X|pages=339–345|volume=88|issue=4|pmid=28214798|doi=10.1136/jnnp-2016-315346}}</ref> The [[American Heart Association]] and [[American Stroke Association]] guidelines in 2015 recommended decreasing the blood pressure to a SBP of 140 mmHg.<ref name=Hem2015/> Evidence that this is useful is tentative as of 2015.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Ma |first1=J |last2=Li |first2=H |last3=Liu |first3=Y |last4=You |first4=C |last5=Huang |first5=S |last6=Ma |first6=L |title=Effects of Intensive Blood Pressure Lowering on Intracerebral Hemorrhage Outcomes: A Meta-Analysis of Randomized Controlled Trials |journal=Turkish Neurosurgery |date=2015 |volume=25 |issue=4 |pages=544–51 |doi=10.5137/1019-5149.JTN.9270-13.0 |pmid=26242330|doi-broken-date=2018-09-10 }}</ref> *Giving [[Factor VII]]a within 4 hours limits the bleeding and formation of a [[hematoma]]. However, it also increases the risk of [[thromboembolism]].<ref name=emedicine>[http://emedicine.medscape.com/article/1163977-treatment eMedicine Specialties > Neurology > Neurological Emergencies > Intracranial Haemorrhage: Treatment & Medication.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090312093658/http://emedicine.medscape.com/article/1163977-treatment |date=2009-03-12 }} By David S Liebeskind, MD. Updated: Aug 7, 2006</ref> It thus overall does not result in better outcomes in those without hemophilia.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Yuan|first1=ZH|last2=Jiang|first2=JK|last3=Huang|first3=WD|last4=Pan|first4=J|last5=Zhu|first5=JY|last6=Wang|first6=JZ|title=A meta-analysis of the efficacy and safety of recombinant activated factor VII for patients with acute intracerebral hemorrhage without hemophilia|journal=Journal of Clinical Neuroscience|date=June 2010|volume=17|issue=6|pages=685–93|pmid=20399668|doi=10.1016/j.jocn.2009.11.020}}</ref> *[[Fresh frozen plasma|Frozen plasma]], [[vitamin K]], [[protamine]], or [[platelet transfusion]]s may be given in case of a [[coagulopathy]].<ref name=emedicine/> Platelets however appear to worsen outcomes in those with spontaneous intracerebral bleeding on antiplatelet medication.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Al-Shahi Salman|first1=R|last2=Law|first2=ZK|last3=Bath|first3=PM|last4=Steiner|first4=T|last5=Sprigg|first5=N|title=Haemostatic therapies for acute spontaneous intracerebral haemorrhage|journal=The Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews|date=17 April 2018|volume=4|pages=CD005951|doi=10.1002/14651858.CD005951.pub4|pmid=29664991}}</ref> *[[Fosphenytoin]] or other [[anticonvulsant]] is given in case of [[seizures]] or lobar hemorrhage.<ref name=emedicine/> *H2 antagonists or proton pump inhibitors are commonly given for to try to prevent [[stress ulcer]]s, a condition linked with ICH.<ref name=emedicine/> *[[Corticosteroids]], were thought to reduce swelling. However, in large controlled studies, corticosteroids have been found to increase mortality rates and are no longer recommended.<ref>{{cite journal|first1=Ian|last1=Roberts|first2=David|last2=Yates|first3=Peter|last3=Sandercock|first4=Barbara|last4=Farrell|title=Effect of intravenous corticosteroids on death within 14 days in 10008 adults with clinically significant head injury (MRC CRASH trial): randomised placebo-controlled trial|journal=Lancet|date=9 October 2016|issn=1474-547X|pages=1321–1328|volume=364|issue=9442|pmid=15474134|doi=10.1016/S0140-6736(04)17188-2|first5=Jonathan|last5=Wasserberg}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Edwards|first1=P|last2=Arango|first2=M|last3=Balica|first3=L|last4=Cottingham|first4=R|last5=El-Sayed|first5=H|first35=collaborators.|title=Final results of MRC CRASH, a randomised placebo-controlled trial of intravenous corticosteroid in adults with head injury-outcomes at 6 months|journal=Lancet|date=undefined NaN|volume=365|issue=9475|pages=1957–9|pmid=15936423|doi=10.1016/s0140-6736(05)66552-x}}</ref>
===Surgery=== Surgery is required if the [[hematoma]] is greater than {{convert|3|cm|0|abbr=on}}, if there is a structural [[vascular]] [[lesion]] or [[lobe (anatomy)|lobar]] [[bleeding|hemorrhage]] in a young patient.<ref name=emedicine/>
*A [[catheter]] may be passed into the brain [[vasculature]] to close off or dilate [[blood vessel]]s, avoiding invasive surgical procedures.<ref>[http://www.csmc.edu/2424.html Cedars-Sinai Health System - Cerebral Hemorrhages] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090312064211/http://csmc.edu/2424.html |date=2009-03-12 }} Retrieved on 02/25/2009</ref> *Aspiration by [[stereotactic surgery]] or [[endoscopic]] drainage may be used in [[basal ganglia]] hemorrhages, although successful reports are limited.<ref name=emedicine/> *A [[Decompressive craniectomy|craniectomy]] may take place, where part of the skull is removed to allow a swelling brain room to expand without being squeezed.
==Prognosis== The risk of death from an intraparenchymal bleed in traumatic brain injury is especially high when the injury occurs in the [[brain stem]].<ref name="Sanders and McKenna">Sanders MJ and McKenna K. 2001. Mosby's Paramedic Textbook, 2nd revised Ed. Chapter 22, "Head and Facial Trauma." Mosby.</ref> Intraparenchymal bleeds within the [[medulla oblongata]] are almost always fatal, because they cause damage to cranial nerve X, the [[vagus nerve]], which plays an important role in [[blood circulation]] and breathing.<ref name="McCaffrey"/> This kind of hemorrhage can also occur in the [[Cerebral cortex|cortex]] or subcortical areas, usually in the [[frontal lobe|frontal]] or [[temporal lobe]]s when due to head injury, and sometimes in the [[cerebellum]].<ref name="McCaffrey"/><ref name="Graham and Gennareli ">Graham DI and Gennareli TA. Chapter 5, "Pathology of Brain Damage After Head Injury" Cooper P and Golfinos G. 2000. ''Head Injury'', 4th Ed. Morgan Hill, New York.</ref>
For spontaneous ICH seen on CT scan, the death rate ([[mortality rate|mortality]]) is 34–50% by 30 days after the insult,<ref name="Yadav07"/> and half of the deaths occur in the first 2 days.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Broderick|first1=J.|last2=Connolly|first2=S.|last3=Feldmann|first3=E.|last4=Hanley|first4=D.|last5=Kase|first5=C.|last6=Krieger|first6=D.|last7=Mayberg|first7=M.|last8=Morgenstern|first8=L.|last9=Ogilvy|first9=C. S.|last10=Vespa|first10=P.|last11=Zuccarello|first11=M.|title=Guidelines for the Management of Spontaneous Intracerebral Hemorrhage in Adults: 2007 Update: A Guideline From the American Heart Association/American Stroke Association Stroke Council, High Blood Pressure Research Council, and the Quality of Care and Outcomes in Research Interdisciplinary Working Group: The American Academy of Neurology affirms the value of this guideline as an educational tool for neurologists|journal=Stroke|date=3 May 2007|volume=38|issue=6|pages=2001–2023|doi=10.1161/strokeaha.107.183689|pmid=17478736}}</ref> Even though the majority of deaths occurs in the first days after ICH, survivors have a long term excess mortality of 27% compared to the general population.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Hansen|first=B.M.|author2=Nilsson O.G.|author3=Anderson H|title=Long term (13 years) prognosis after primary intracerebral haemorrhage: a prospective population based study of long term mortality, prognostic factors and causes of death|journal=Journal of Neurology, Neurosurgery & Psychiatry|date=Oct 2013|volume=84|issue=10|pages=1150–1155|doi=10.1136/jnnp-2013-305200|pmid=23715913|url=http://jnnp.bmj.com/content/early/2013/05/27/jnnp-2013-305200|display-authors=etal|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140222034200/http://jnnp.bmj.com/content/early/2013/05/27/jnnp-2013-305200|archivedate=2014-02-22|df=}}</ref>
==Epidemiology== It accounts for 20% of all cases of [[cerebrovascular disease]] in the United States, behind [[cerebral thrombosis]] (40%) and [[cerebral embolism]] (30%).<ref>Page 117 in: {{cite book |author1=Henry S. Schutta |author2=Lechtenberg, Richard |title=Neurology practice guidelines |publisher=M. Dekker |location=New York |year=1998 |pages= |isbn=978-0-8247-0104-8 |oclc= |doi= |accessdate=}}</ref>
==Research== The inflammatory response triggered by stroke has been viewed as harmful in the early stage, focusing on blood-borne leukocytes, neutrophils and macrophages, and resident [[microglia]] and [[astrocyte]]s.<ref name="Wang 2010">{{cite journal |author=Wang J |title=Preclinical and clinical research on inflammation after intracerebral hemorrhage |journal=Prog. Neurobiol. |volume=92 |issue=4 |pages=463–77 |date=December 2010 |pmid=20713126 |pmc=2991407 |doi=10.1016/j.pneurobio.2010.08.001 |url=}}</ref> A human postmortem study shows that inflammation occurs early and persists for several days after ICH.<ref name="pmid20420814">{{cite journal |vauthors=Wu H, Zhang Z, Hu X, Zhao R, Song Y, Ban X, Qi J, Wang J | title=Dynamic changes of inflammatory markers in brain after hemorrhagic stroke in humans: a postmortem study| journal=Brain Research| year=2010 | pages=111–1117 | volume=1342 | issue=1342 |pmid=20420814| pmc=2885522 | doi=10.1016/j.brainres.2010.04.033}}</ref> Modulating microglial activation and polarization might mitigate intracerebral hemorrhage-induced brain injury and improve brain repair.<ref name="pmid28524175">{{cite journal |vauthors=Lan X, Han X, Li Q, Yang QW, Wang J | title=Modulators of microglial activation and polarization after intracerebral haemorrhage| journal=Nat Rev Neurol | year=2017 | pages=420–433 | volume=13 | issue=7 |pmid= 28524175 | doi=10.1038/nrneurol.2017.69 | pmc=5575938}}</ref> A new area of interest is the role of [[mast cell]]s in ICH.<ref>{{cite journal |url=http://www.nature.com/jcbfm/journal/v30/n4/abs/jcbfm2009282a.html |title= Mast Cells as Early Responders in the Regulation of Acute Blood–Brain Barrier Changes after Cerebral Ischemia and Hemorrhage|accessdate=2010-04-02 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100608195215/http://www.nature.com/jcbfm/journal/v30/n4/abs/jcbfm2009282a.html |archivedate=2010-06-08 |df= | doi = 10.1038/jcbfm.2009.282 |pmid= 20087366|volume=30 |issue= 4|year=2010 |journal=Journal of Cerebral Blood Flow & Metabolism |pages=689–702 | last1 = Johannes Lindsberg | first1 = Perttu | last2 = Strbian | first2 = Daniel | last3 = Karjalainen-Lindsberg | first3 = Marja-Liisa|pmc=2949160 }}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==Further reading== *{{cite journal|last1=Hemphill JC|first1=3rd|last2=Greenberg|first2=SM|last3=Anderson|first3=CS|last4=Becker|first4=K|last5=Bendok|first5=BR|last6=Cushman|first6=M|last7=Fung|first7=GL|last8=Goldstein|first8=JN|last9=Macdonald|first9=RL|last10=Mitchell|first10=PH|last11=Scott|first11=PA|last12=Selim|first12=MH|last13=Woo|first13=D|title=Guidelines for the Management of Spontaneous Intracerebral Hemorrhage: A Guideline for Healthcare Professionals From the American Heart Association/American Stroke Association|journal=Stroke: A Journal of Cerebral Circulation|date=28 May 2015|pmid=26022637|doi=10.1161/STR.0000000000000069|volume=46|issue=7|pages=2032–60|pmc=4462131}}
